title: James Horncastle Serie A briefing : Pulisic and Maignan derby heroics , Conte staying , imperial Roma
body_text:
Winter is coming. Temperatures have dropped. Snowflakes are falling in cascades. All I Want for Christmas is You is on the radio. Panettone is on sale. Serie A is using the orange ball.
This decision made little sense in Sardinia on Saturday afternoon. The sun was out for Cagliariâ€™s first game since a U.S. consortium bought a minority stake in the club over the international break.

Perhaps the use of the Puma Orbita Serie A High-Vis FIFA Pro ball was justifiable for other reasons. Goals have been in short supply in Italy this season. There were only 244 going into the November break. Seven leagues in Europe counted more. The 17 0-0s in Serie A represented an extreme outlier. By comparison, the runner-up for most stalemates this season, the set-piece Premier League, has had 10 fewer. Might changing the ballâ€™s colour have an effect? Cavolo! It did

There were six goals at the Unipol Domus on Saturday and there could have been more. Genoa twice got in front. Cagliari came back and took the lead. Arguably Italyâ€™s blusteriest ground, the whipping wind fooled Cagliari goalkeeper Elia Caprile, whose recent form had been rewarded with an Italy call-up for the qualifiers against Moldova and Norway.
Aaron Martinâ€™s freak free kick, an equalising cross, got lifted by a gale, then fell so hard it bounced over Caprile and clinched a 3-3 draw. â€œWe played football,â€ Genoa coach Daniele De Rossi said. For the love of God, thank you.
It was a welcome change in conversation from Italyâ€™s shortcomings in World Cup qualification.
They ranged from a 4-1 defeat by Norway at San Siro, the Azzurriâ€™s heaviest at home since 1955, the indignity of Gianluca Mancini pinching Erling Haalandâ€™s bum in an attempt to put him off his game only for him score twice, the desperate and unedifying complaints from national team coach Gennaro Gattuso about the number of spots Africa and South America get at the tournament, and the calls for more time with the players before the play-off semi-final against almighty Northern Ireland in March.
Napoliâ€™s trials and tribulations
The melodrama and all too familiar head-banging caused by the national teamâ€™s travails distracted from another big story down in Naples. After losing to Bologna a fortnight ago, Antonio Conte needed a break. Rather than stay in Naples and train the players not on international duty, he spent a week in Turin, the place his family call home. This led to speculation about his future.

â€œI read fantasies about Conteâ€™s resignation on the web,â€ Napoli owner Aurelio De Laurentiis tweeted. He reassured the fans it was â€œnonsenseâ€ and marvelled at Conteâ€™s willingness â€œto sacrifice every second of his life for his professionâ€. Conte returned on Monday, recharged. But the seismograph around Mount Vesuvius began violently scribbling on Thursday.
Napoli expressed their â€œastonishment and dismayâ€ at the decision to commit an investigation into false accounting and player trading between 2019 and 2021 to trial. Napoli have denied wrongdoing and stated they â€œdid not derive any advantage from the disputed transactionsâ€, involving Kostas Manolas and Victor Osimhen, whose move from Lille coincided with four Napoli players going the other way. The only one of note was Orestis Karnezis, a veteran backup goalkeeper, then 35. The rest were unknowns, Claudio Manzi, Luigi Liguori and Ciro Palmieri, who never played for Lille. The quartet were valued at â‚¬20million.
Napoli have always maintained the transfers were legitimate and, pointedly and rather amusingly, raised â€œa perfectly comparable caseâ€ from the past in which an investigation into Interâ€™s player-trading in 2018 and 2019 was dismissed.
Nevertheless, in the fiercely tribal world of Italian football, the decision by a preliminary hearing judge in Rome to commit the case to trial has raised questions. For instance, is the evidence used in support of that decision, some of it published by La Repubblica, not enough for Giuseppe Chine, the lead prosecutor of the Italian Football Federationâ€™s disciplinary committee, to reopen a sporting investigation into player trading and transfer values, as was the case with Juventus, who were docked 10 points in 2023. Apparently not.
Napoli have won the league twice in the meantime. They moved back to the top of the table on Saturday night with an emphatic win over Atalanta. Already three goals to the good at half-time, Romelu Lukaku was in the stands and then on the sidelines acting like Conteâ€™s assistant coach. â€œI love Romelu too much to advise him to become a coach,â€ Conte laughed. Itâ€™s a gruelling job, even if the wins he keeps racking up gloss over how hard. Napoli remain unbeaten at the Maradona this calendar year in Serie A and wonâ€™t give up their title without a fight.

Are Bologna title contenders?
The Felsinei could have been roughed up by Udinese. Kosta Runjaicâ€™s team are one of the most physical in the league and had only lost once at the Bluenergy Stadium all season. Bologna were also missing their first-choice goalkeeper, Lukasz Skorupski, their best centre-back, Jhon Lucumi, who was late back from international duty, while Remo Freuler and Lewis Ferguson, their midfield dynamos, were either unfit, or in the Scotâ€™s case, worn out from qualifying for the World Cup.
It didnâ€™t matter. Bologna suffered in the first half. They got knocked about a bit and Riccardo Orsolini missed a penalty. Nae bother, as Scotland midfielder Ferguson might say. They stayed in the game, grew into it, and won 3-0. In retrospect, Napoliâ€™s crisis-provoking defeat by Bologna a fortnight ago doesnâ€™t look so bad.
Unbeaten in 11 games in all competitions, Bolognaâ€™s rise continues. It can be traced back to the team spirit and sense of belonging forged by Sinisa Mihajlovic, the modernity brought by Thiago Motta, and the experience of playing Champions League football and winning the Coppa Italia under Vincenzo Italiano.
A virtuous circle has turned anew regardless of the managerial churn. Bologna are the prospective successors to Atalanta. General manager Giovanni Sartori joined one from the other and his magic touch in recruitment, particularly the unappreciated depth at the Renato Dallâ€™Ara, is now being felt. Sartori was one of Atalantaâ€™s secrets. He was more in the shadows than Gian Piero Gasperini, and if the spell, for now, seems broken in Bergamo, it is not in Bologna, nor is it in Rome.
Roma are for real
In the neighbourhood of Garbatella, one of the hotbeds of Roma support in the capital, a mural has been painted. It depicts Gasperini as a wizard. In it, he stirs a cauldron, mixing a heady brew of grit, heart and sweat. â€œI look like a cross between Merlin and the Befana,â€ Gasperini said. â€œItâ€™s wonderful. The ingredients are fantastic. I couldnâ€™t agree more. Theyâ€™re the main ones, then we try to add spice and salt.â€

What sorcery is this? Romaâ€™s 3-1 win in Cremona on Sunday meant the lead in Serie A changed three times over the weekend. Roma flew past Bologna and Napoli to resume their place at the top and it is â€œnot by chanceâ€ in Gasperiniâ€™s estimation. After carrying on the good work of Claudio Ranieri, the team is more and more in Gasperiniâ€™s image. Mancini, a centre-back, setting up Zeki Celik, a wing-back, for Romaâ€™s second goal against Udinese before the international break, was a sign of the confidence this team is gaining in attack.
At the Zini, Roma were near perfect. Matias Soule keeps scoring the same goal. A striker-less starting XI then got one, as was the case in Reggio Emilia, from a striker coming off the bench. On that occasion, it was Artem Dovbyk.

As the January transfer window approaches, Roma have started to be linked with Manchester Unitedâ€™s Joshua Zirkzee. It is indicative of a lack of confidence in the teamâ€™s forwards. Little was expected of Ferguson, then, as he entered the game in Cremona. But the Brighton & Hove Albion loanee and Gasperiniâ€™s other subs, Neil El Aynaoui and Stephan El Shaarawy, helped kill off Cremonese.

Top at this stage for the first time in 11 years, Roma could have been caught by Inter later in the day, depending on the outcome of the seasonâ€™s first Derby della Madonnina.
Alas, Inter ran into Mike Maignan.
Magic Mike
Milanâ€™s goalkeeper and captain has been at his best this season. After saving a penalty against Roma to preserve a 1-0 win at the Stadio Olimpico this month, Maignan got in the way of former team-mate Hakan Calhanoglu equalising from the spot to secure another quintessentially Max Allegri win.
It was Corto Muso; by a nose, 1-0 all over again. Christian Pulisic didnâ€™t want the Player of the Match award, insisting it was only right that Maignan collected it. The American admitted not feeling â€œ100 per cent sharpâ€ on his first start since the injury he suffered while on international duty in October, yet he still managed to keep up his ratio of a goal or an assist every 57 minutes when fit for Milan this season.

The Madonnina was, on one level, a tale of two goalkeepers. If Maignan has often been the difference in Milanâ€™s tight wins, Interâ€™s Yann Sommer has made mistakes in tight losses to Udinese, Juventus and the cousins. As we head into a Champions League week, Inter coach Cristian Chivu can expect to keep getting questions about Sommerâ€™s place in the side, while Milanâ€™s executive team know Maignanâ€™s future will, once again, be a topic of discussion.
Maignanâ€™s contract is up in the summer. Milan didnâ€™t blink in 2021 when they refused to give into Donnarummaâ€™s salary demands. They showed themselves more than capable of replacing him, too. Will there be a repeat with Maignan? The considerable signing-on fee he commands might still be less than the transfer fee for a successor.
Maignan is, along with Romaâ€™s Mile Svilar, the best goalkeeper in Serie A this season. Serie A can change the ball from white to high-vis, but Maigan continues to keep it out. In the long run the two No 1s, Maignan and Svilar, might be the difference between who, out of Milan and Roma, finishes No 1 come the end of the season.
